revision.comment: Updating information on the page and correcting it: OHSAS 18001 was not more specific to British needs - it was developed internationally - see Development - nor did the cited reference say it was; nor was it especially for the O&G sector, which again, the cited reference did not state.
revision.text:
{{For|the radio frequency standard|ISO/IEC 18000}} [[File:OHSAS 18001-Borjpardis.jpg|thumbnail|Certificate of conformity to OHSAS 18001:2007]] '''OHSAS 18001''', Occupational Health and Safety Assessment Series, (officially '''BS OHSAS 18001''') is a [[British Standard]] for occupational health and safety [[management system]]s. Compliance with it enables organizations to demonstrate that they have a system in place for occupational health and safety. BS OHSAS 18001 is being replaced by [[ISO 45001|ISO 45001]], which was published in March 2018 by the [[International Organization for Standardization]].<ref>{{cite web |title=ISO 45001 |url=https://www.iso.org/iso-45001-occupational-health-and-safety.html |website=www.iso.org |publisher=ISO official website |accessdate=25 September 2018}}</ref> Organizations which are certified to BS OHSAS 18001 should migrate to ISO 45001 by March 2021 if they want to retain a recognized certification.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.iso.org/news/ref2270.html|title=Let the migration begin|work=ISO|access-date=2018-03-13|language=en}}</ref>
==Origins== Organizations worldwide recognize the need to control and improve health and safety performance and do so with occupational health and safety management systems (OHSMS). However, before 1999 there was an increase of national standards and proprietary certification schemes to choose from. This caused confusion and fragmentation in the market and undermined the credibility of individual schemes.
==Development==
Recognising this deficit, an international collaboration called the Occupational Health and Safety Assessment Series (OHSAS) Project Group was formed to create a single unified approach. The Group comprised representatives from [[Standards organisation#National standards bodies|national standards bodies]], academic bodies, accreditation bodies, certification bodies and occupational safety and health institutions,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ilo.org/wcmsp5/groups/public/---ed_norm/---relconf/documents/meetingdocument/wcms_091362.pdf|title=International Labour Office Report, Page 2, Footnote 3|publisher=}}</ref> with the UK’s national standards body, [[BSI Group]], providing the secretariat.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://iso14000expert.com/publications/OHSASsurvey.pdf|title=Occupational Health and Safety (OH&S) Management Systems,Standards and Certificates Survey - to 31 December 2005|publisher=}}</ref>
Drawing on the best of existing standards and schemes, the OHSAS Project Group published the OHSAS 18000 Series in 1999. The Series consisted of two specifications: 18001 provided requirements for an OHS management system and 18002 gave implementation guidelines. As of 2005, around 16,000 organizations in more than 80 countries were using the OHSAS 18001 specification.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bsigroup.com/en/Assessment-and-certification-services/management-systems/Business-areas/Occupational-health-and-safety-management/Updated-OHSAS-18001-coming-in-July/|title=BS OHSAS 18001 - Occupational Health & Safety - BSI Group|website=www.bsigroup.com}}</ref> By 2009 more than 54,000 certificates had been issued in 116 countries to OHSAS or equivalent OHSMS standards.
==Adoption as British Standard== The OHSAS 18001 specification was updated in July 2007. Among other changes, the new specification was more closely aligned with the structures of [[ISO 9000]] and [[ISO 14000]] so that organizations could more easily adopt OHSAS 18001 alongside existing management systems.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.bsigroup.com/LocalFiles/en-GB/iso-45001/Resources/BSI-ISO45001-Revision-Whitepaper-EN-UK.pdf|title=ISO 45001 Whitepaper: A new International Standard for Occupational Health and Safety Management Systems|last=|first=|date=|website=BSIgroup.com|publisher=[[BSI Group|British Standards Institution]]|access-date=2016-11-18}}</ref> Additionally, the "health" component of "health and safety" was given greater emphasis.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bsigroup.com/en/about-bsi/News-Room/BSI-News-Content/Disciplines/Risk-Management/BS-OHSAS-180012007/|title=Press releases, news, media centre, standards, ISO, 9001, 14001, 18001 - BSI Group|website=www.bsigroup.com}}</ref>
Later, the BSI Group decided to adopt OHSAS 18001 as a British standard.<ref name=":0" /> BSI Group subsequently adopted the updated 18002 guidance specification for publication as BS OHSAS 18002 in 2008.
==How they work== {{technical|section|date=June 2013}} Its supporters claim that an occupational health and safety management system (OHSMS) promotes a safe and healthy working environment by providing a framework that helps organizations to: * Identify and control health and safety risks * Reduce the potential for accidents * Aid legal compliance * Improve overall performance
The OHSAS 18000 standards provide organizations with the elements of an effective safety management system which can be integrated with other management systems and help organizations achieve better occupational health and safety performance and economic objectives.
BS OHSAS 18001 specifies requirements for an OH&S management system to help an organization develop and implement a policy and objectives, which take into account legal requirements and information about OH&S risks. It applies to all types and sizes of organizations and accommodates diverse geographical, cultural and social conditions.
BS OHSAS 18002 provides guidance for establishing, implementing or improving a management system which is based on OHSAS 18001 and demonstrating successful implementation of OHSAS 18001.
OHSAS 18001 can be aligned with existing ISO 9001 and ISO 14001 management systems. Historically many organizations start with the quality management system ISO 9001, then add the environment management requirements from ISO 14001. Many organizations now look at implementing all three standards at once which can minimize costs and disruption. The standards can be integrated using a standard such as BSI’s [[PAS 99]].
==Disambiguation== The OHSAS 18000 standards were written and published wholly outside of the [[International Organization for Standardization]] (ISO) framework. To avoid confusion, [[ISO/IEC 18000|ISO 18000]] does exist – but it is a [[radio-frequency identification]] standard.
== References == <!--- See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Footnotes on how to create references using tags which will then appear here automatically --> {{Reflist}}
== External links == * {{Official website|http://www.bsigroup.com/en-GB/ohsas-18001-occupational-health-and-safety/}}

According to 2007 statistics from the World Health Organization (WHO), Australia has the third-highest prevalence of overweight adults in the [[English-speaking world]].<ref name="forbes"/>'''Obesity in Australia''' is an "epidemic"<ref name="australian2">{{cite web |url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/childhood-obesity-epidemic-a-myth/story-e6frg6n6-1111118515918 |title=Childhood obesity epidemic a myth, says research |accessdate=5 July 2009 |author1=Siobhain Ryan |author2=Natasha Bita |lastauthoramp=yes |date=9 January 2009 |work= |publisher=The Australian}}</ref> with "increasing frequency."<ref name="australian2" /><ref name="parliament">{{cite web |url=http://www.aph.gov.au/library/intguide/SP/obesity.htm |title=Overweight and obesity in Australia |accessdate=5 July 2009 |author=Mandy Biggs |date=5 October 2006 |work= |publisher=Parliament of Australia}}</ref> ''[[The Medical Journal of Australia]]'' found that [[obesity]] in Australia more than doubled in the two decades preceding 2003,<ref name="theage">{{cite news |url=http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2003/05/04/1051987606983.html |title=Australia, US the most overweight |accessdate=5 July 2009 |author=Amanda Dunn |date=5 May 2003 |work= |publisher=The Age |location=Melbourne}}</ref> and the unprecedented rise in obesity has been compared to the same [[Obesity in the United States|health crisis in America]].<ref name="theage" /> {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2010}} The rise in obesity has been attributed to poor eating habits in the country closely related to the availability of [[fast food]] since the 1970s,<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2014-05-29/australian-obesity-rates-climbing-fastest-in-the-world/5485724 |title=Australian obesity rates climbing faster than anywhere else in the world, study shows |work=abc.net.au |date=29 May 2014 |accessdate=28 August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.news.com.au/national/obesity-levels-show-australia-is-the-chubby-country/story-e6frfkvr-1226064083008 |title=Australia becomes fast food nation and moves to 11th position for spending on takeaway |work=[[news.com.au]] |date=27 May 2011 |accessdate=28 August 2015}}</ref> [[sedentary lifestyle]]s and a decrease in the [[Manual labour|labour workforce]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.abs.gov.au/ausstats/abs@.nsf/latestProducts/6202.0Media%20Release1Jul%202015 |title=Australia's unemployment rate increased to 6.3 per cent in July 2015 |work=[[Australian Bureau of Statistics]] |date=6 August 2015 |accessdate=28 August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://theconversation.com/factcheck-is-australia-losing-one-manufacturing-job-every-19-minutes-15917 |title=FactCheck: is Australia losing one manufacturing job every 19 minutes? |work=theconversation.com |date=16 July 2013 |accessdate=28 August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cancercouncil.com.au/68145/news-media/latest-news-news-media/cc-news/fast-food-exposing-the-truth/ |title=Exposing the truth on fast food restaurants |work=www.cancercouncil.com.au ([[Cancer Council Australia]]) |accessdate=28 August 2015}}</ref>
==Classification of obesity== Weight is measured by using the Body Mass Index scale (BMI). This is determined by dividing weight in kilograms by height in metres, squared. If someone is overweight their BMI will be at 25 or more.<ref name="government"/> If someone is obese their BMI will be at 30 or more. {| class="wikitable" style="float: right;" !Classification !Body Mass Index (BMI) |- |Underweight |< 18.50 |- |Normal Range |18.50-24.99 |- |Overweight |>25.00 |- |Obese class 1 |30-34.99 |- |Obese class 2 |35-39.99 |- |Obese class 3 |> 40.00 |}
==Prevalence of obesity in the Australian population== 1 in 4 children are overweight (25%) and 2 in 3 adults are overweight (63%)
===Australian adults===
In a study published in 2015 by the US Journal of Economics and Human Biology, obesity is found to have the largest impact on men aged over 75, and women aged between 60-74.<ref>{{Cite journal |url=http://bv8ja7kw5x.search.serialssolutions.com/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&ctx_enc=info%3Aofi%2Fenc%3AUTF-8&rfr_id=info:sid/summon.serialssolutions.com&rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&rft.genre=article&rft.atitle=Obesity+and+health+expenditures%3A+Evidence+from+Australia&rft.jtitle=Economics+%26+Human+Biology&rft.au=Buchmueller%2C+Thomas+C&rft.au=Johar%2C+Meliyanni&rft.date=2015-04-01&rft.issn=1570-677X&rft.eissn=1873-6130&rft.volume=17&rft.spage=42&rft.epage=58&rft_id=info:doi/10.1016%2Fj.ehb.2015.01.001&rft.externalDBID=n%2Fa&rft.externalDocID=10_1016_j_ehb_2015_01_001&paramdict=en-US |title=Obesity and health expenditures. Evidence from Australia |last=Buchmueller |first=Thomas |date=1 April 2015 |journal=Economics and Human Biology |doi= |pmid=|access-date = 1 April 2015 |issue= |volume=17}}</ref>
In 2005, a study was conducted by the Australian Bureau of Statistics that compared the results of a 2004-05 survey with those conducted in the preceding 15 years. The results showed an increase in the number and proportion of adults who are overweight or obese. Over the four surveys, the number of overweight or obese adults increased from 4.6 million in 1989-90 to 5.4 million in 1995, 6.6 million in 2001 and 7.4 million in 2004-05.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.ausstats.abs.gov.au/Ausstats/subscriber.nsf/0/A54D036CCD28533ACA2573DA001C9166/$File/47190_2004-05.pdf |title=Overweight and Obesity in Adults |date=2004 |website=Australian Bureau of Statistics |publisher=}}</ref>
In 2007, the [[World Health Organization]] (WHO) found that 67.4% of Australian adults are overweight,<ref name="forbes">{{cite web |url=https://www.forbes.com/2007/02/07/worlds-fattest-countries-forbeslife-cx_ls_0208worldfat_2.html |title=World's Fattest Countries |accessdate=12 February 2009 |author=Lauren Streib |date=8 February 2007 |work= |publisher=Forbes}}</ref> ranking 21st in the world, and third out of the major countries in the [[English-speaking world]], behind the [[Obesity in the United States|United States]] (ranked 9th) and [[Obesity in New Zealand|New Zealand]] (ranked 17th).<ref name="forbes" /> A 2005 WHO study found that just over 20% of Australian adults are obese,<ref name="parliament" /> which is expected to rise to roughly 29% in 2010 if current trends continue. (Update) about 29 to 30% of Australians are obese in 2017.<ref name="parliament" />
In the 2005 National Health Survey, 53.6% of Australians reported being overweight with 18% falling into the "obese" category. Those numbers rose to 65% overweight and 29% obese in 2016.<ref name="stats">[http://www.aihw.gov.au/publications/aus/ah06/ah06-c07.pdf National Health Survey stats]</ref> This is nearly double the reported number from 1995, when 30% of adults were overweight and 11% were obese.<ref name="government">{{cite web |url=http://www.health.gov.au/internet/main/Publishing.nsf/Content/health-pubhlth-strateg-hlthwt-obesity.htm |title=About Overweight and Obesity |publisher=The Department of Health, Australian Government |access-date=10 April 2015}}</ref> Such representations would be skewed downward as people tend to overestimate their height and under-report their weight, the two key criteria to determine a BMI reading.<ref name="parliament" /> In the National Health Survey, obesity reports were fairly common across the board, with no major outliers. [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]] had the lowest incidence of obesity, at 17.0% of the population, with [[South Australia]] reporting the highest numbers at 19.6%.<ref name="stats" /> By 2014, [[Canberra]] recorded an obesity rate of 25% which was placing significant strain on ageing health care infrastructure.<ref name="ocp">{{Cite news |url=http://www.canberratimes.com.au/act-news/obesity-crisis-proves-a-weighty-issue-for-canberra-hospital-20140428-37ebm.html |title=Obesity crisis proves a weighty issue for Canberra Hospital |author=Ewa Kretowicz |accessdate=29 April 2014 |date=29 April 2014 |work=The Canberra Times |publisher=Fairfax Media}}</ref>
In a study conducted by The Obesity Society, between 2001 and 2025, the adult population prevalence of normal healthy weight will decrease from 40.6% to 22.9%. In conjunction with this, the prevalence of obesity will increase from 20.5% to 33.9%. It is also estimated that by the time 25- to 29-year-olds of 2000 reach the age of 60-64 (2040), over one third will be obese.<ref>{{Cite journal |url= |title=Projected Progression of the Prevalence of Obesity in Australia |date=April 2012 |journal=Obesity |doi= 10.1038/oby.2010.338|pmid=|access-date =}}</ref>
A recent study reported that based on figures from the National Health Survey and/or Australian Health Survey the prevalence of overweight and obesity increased from 56.3% in 1995 to 61.2% in 2007–2008 and 62.8% in 2011–2012. This was attributed largely to an increase in the level of obesity from 18.7% to 27.5% over the period, with the proportion of overweight adults remaining similar (35.3–37.6%).<ref>{{Cite journal |url=http://bmjopen.bmj.com/content/6/5/e010405.full |title=Socioeconomic disadvantage and its implications for population health planning of obesity and overweight, using cross-sectional data from general practices from a regional catchment in Australia |vauthors=Ghosh A, Charlton K, Batterham M |date=3 May 2016 |journal=BMJ Open |doi=10.1136/bmjopen-2015-010405| access-date = 5 May 2016 |issue=5 |volume=6 |pages=e010405}}</ref> The study argues for preventive health measures to be gender-specific and specific to socioeconomic disadvantage within populations.
Age-standardization of the 2011-12 Australian Health Survey was done in a recent study which reported 28.3% of Australian adults to be obese with 63.4% adults being overweight or obese.<ref>{{Cite journal |url=http://bmcpublichealth.biomedcentral.com/articles/10.1186/1471-2458-14-557 |title=Using data from patient interactions in primary care for population level chronic disease surveillance: The Sentinel Practices Data Sourcing (SPDS) project |vauthors=Ghosh A, Charlton K, Girdo L, Batterham M |date=5 June 2014 |journal=BMC Public Health |doi=10.1186/1471-2458-14-557| access-date = 2 Jan 2015 |issue=1 |volume=14 |pmid=24899119 |pmc=4077676}}</ref> A subsequent analysis published in 2016 reported that despite of obesity and overweight together being the second highest contributor to the burden of disease in Australia <ref>{{cite web |title=Overweight and obesity |publisher=Australian Institute of Health and Welfare |url=http://www.aihw.gov.au/overweight-and-obesity/}}</ref> the regular screening and recording of measures of obesity and overweight in primary care setting especially within regional Australian catchments was much lower than optimal.<ref>{{Cite journal |url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/ajr.12264/full |title=Depressed, anxious and breathless missing out: Weight screening in general practice in a regional catchment of New South Wales |last=Ghosh A |first=Abhijeet |date=23 Dec 2015 |journal=Australian Journal of Rural Health |doi=10.1111/ajr.12264|access-date = 19 Mar 2016}}</ref>
=== Indigenous population === Indigenous Australians have Australia's highest level of obesity.<ref name="abc2">{{cite web |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/newsitems/200312/s1006987.htm |title=Obesity epidemic hits Indigenous Australia |accessdate=5 July 2009 |date=10 December 2003 |work= |publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation}}</ref> A 2001 study showing that 31% of [[Aboriginal Australians]] and [[Torres Strait Islanders]] were obese, nearly double the national average at that time.<ref name="abc2"/>
The health and well being of Australian Indigenous youth is becoming increasingly concerning. A cross sectional study (Valery, Moloney, Cotterill, Harris, Sinha & Green, 2009) found that 46% of the total population, of participants, were overweight or obese. Of that population, 38% had enlarged waist circumferences, 43% had acanthosis nigricans present and 27% had hypertension. With this high population of overweight and obese Indigenous youth, it puts major implications on the public [[Health care in Australia|health system]].<ref>{{Cite journal |url= |title=Prevalence of obesity and metabolic syndrome in Indigenous Australian youths |last=Valery, Moloney, Cotterill, Harris, Sinha & Green |date=2009 |journal=Obesity Reviews |doi=10.1111/j.1467-789X2008.00545 |pmid=|access-date =}}</ref>
A [[University of Alberta]] study, conducted in 2006, noted that 60% of Aboriginal Australians over the age of 35 in Western Australia tested positive for [[Type 2 diabetes|diabetes]].<ref name="canada">{{cite web |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/canadianpress/article/ALeqM5ieXed7l8XssHRLx1_B9Iuq7SfjuQ |title=International study links Aboriginal health, lifestyle, local decision-making |accessdate=5 July 2009 |date=3 July 2009 |work= |publisher=The Canadian Press}}</ref> Health issues such as heart disease, obesity, and diabetes have lowered the life expectancy for Aboriginal Australians to 17 years below the national life expectancy, a gap that continues to grow.<ref name="canada"/>
Professor Paul Zimmet at Monash University, who conducted the aforementioned study of diabetes rates amongst Asian immigrants, released figures at the Diabetes in Indigenous People Forum in Melbourne, estimating the rate of diabetes from poor diet at 24% of all Torres Strait Islanders<ref name="couriermail">{{cite news |url=http://www.news.com.au/couriermail/story/0,23739,20745401-5003426,00.html |title=Threat to entire races |accessdate=5 July 2009 |author=Tamara McLean |date=13 November 2006 |work= |publisher=The Courier-Mail}}</ref> and remarked that unless extra steps are taken with these groups, Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders will die out within 100 years.<ref name="couriermail" />
=== Immigrant populations === Individuals who migrate to Australia moving from a low income nation, have a greater tendency to undergo an increase in weight.<ref>{{Cite journal |url=http://bv8ja7kw5x.search.serialssolutions.com/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&ctx_enc=info%3Aofi%2Fenc%3AUTF-8&rfr_id=info:sid/summon.serialssolutions.com&rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&rft.genre=article&rft.atitle=Migration%2C+Acculturation+and+Environment%3A+Determinants+of+Obesity+among+Iranian+Migrants+in+Australia&rft.jtitle=International+Journal+of+Environmental+Research+and+Public+Health&rft.au=Maryam+Delavari&rft.au=Anders+Larrabee+S%C3%B8nderlund&rft.au=David+Mellor&rft.au=Mohammadreza+Mohebbi&rft.date=2015-02-01&rft.issn=1661-7827&rft.eissn=1660-4601&rft.volume=12&rft.issue=2&rft.spage=1083&rft.externalDocID=3613670441&paramdict=en-US |title=Migration, Acculturation and Environment: Determinants of Obesity among Iranian Migrants in Australia |last=Delavari |first=Maryam |date=1 February 2015 |journal=International Journal of Environmental Research and Public Health |doi= |pmid=|access-date = 2015-03-31 |issue=2 |volume=12}}</ref> A study done by Delavari et al. (2012) suggested that many immigrant groups showed signs of obesogenic lifestyle behaviours after migrating from low-HDI to high-HDI.<ref>{{Cite journal |url= |title=Experiences of migration and the determinants of obesity among recent Iranian immigrants in Victoria, Australia |last=Delavari, M., Farrelly, A., Renzaho, A., Mellor, D., & Swinburn, B. |date=22 June 2012 |journal=Journal of Ethnicity & Health |doi=10.1080/13557858.2012.698255 |pmid= |volume=18 |pages=66–82}}</ref> It has also been found that Sudanese refugees in Australia have an increased risk of obesity compared to the general population. (Rezaho et al. 2014) <ref>{{Cite journal |url= |title=Obesity, type 2 diabetes an high blood pressure amongst recently arrived Sudanese refugees in Queensland, Australia |last=Renzaho, A., Bilial, P., & Marks, G. |date=2014 |journal=Journal of Immigrant Minority Health |doi=10.1007/s10903-013-9791-y |pmid= |accessdate= |volume=16 |pages=86–94}}</ref>
First-generation immigrants to Australia are more obese and have higher rates of obesity-related behaviours than white Australians or Australians of foreign ancestry whose families have been in the country at least two generations.{{citation needed|date=December 2011}} A study conducted by the International Diabetes Institute at [[Monash University]] showed that Asians, Pacific Islanders, and Middle Eastern immigrants who moved to Australia were diagnosed with diabetes at a higher level than the average.{{citation needed|date=December 2011}} The increase was explained by the adoption of a Western diet in place of a more healthy "traditional" diet more common in their native countries, as well as adopting a more sedentary lifestyle which is ubiquitous in developed countries.{{citation needed|date=December 2011}}
===Australian children=== {{See|Childhood obesity in Australia}}
The percentage of overweight and obese children in Australia, despite rapid increases in the 1980s and the first half of the 1990s, have remained mostly steady for the past 10 years, with 23 to 24% of Australians under the age of 18 classified as overweight, and 5 to 6% of the same demographic classified as obese.<ref name="australian2" />
A study done by Nichols et al. (2011) found there has been a decreasing trend in overweight and obese preschool children, in Victoria, between 1999 and 2007. Among 2-year-old children, there was a decrease in the obesity of these children from 13.5% in 1999 to 12.4% in 2007 and in the 3.5-year-old children a substantial decrease from 18.5% in 1999 to 15.4% in 2007.<ref>{{Cite journal |url= |title=Decreasing trends in overweight and obesity among an Australian population of preschool children. |last=Nichols, de Silva-Sanigorski, Cleary, Goldfeld, Colahan & Swinburn |date=2011 |journal=International Journal of Obesity |doi=10.1038/ijo.2011.64 |pmid=|access-date = |volume=35 |pages=916–924}}</ref>
Increased media attention on [[childhood obesity]], in 2007 and 2008 especially, caused many researchers to print findings that the rate of obesity for children has reached a plateau<ref name="australian2" /> or that the claims are simply "exaggerated."<ref name="australian2" /><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.smh.com.au/articles/2008/05/31/1211654356335.html |title=Obesity epidemic exaggerated: report |accessdate=5 July 2009 |date=31 May 2008 |work= |publisher=Sydney Morning Herald}}</ref> The reports caused Dr. [[Rosanna Capolingua]], President of the [[Australian Medical Association]], to issue a statement admonishing people and media outlets for "trivialising" the issue.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://growingupinaustralia.gov.au/pubs/asr/2015/asr2015c.html#c3-8 |title=AMA: Don't trivialise childhood obesity |accessdate=5 July 2009 |date=31 May 2008 |work= |publisher=The Courier-Mail}}</ref>
A Western Australian study (Bell et al. 2011) showed that overweight and obese primary school children have greater medical complications due to their weight status. Overweight and obese children were more likely to complain and suffer from [[depression (mood)|depression]], [[anxiety]], bullying, headaches, enuresis and musculoskeletal pain. The most common site of the musculoskeletal pain was in the knees with overweight children 1.3 times and obese children 3 times more likely to complain about it than the control children. Overweight and obese children also had significantly higher levels of hypertension (control 3.4%, overweight 7.3%, obese 19%), impaired glucose tolerance (control: normal, overweight 1.3%, obese 5.3%) and hyperinsulinism (control 8%, overweight 19.5%, obese 38.9%).<ref>{{Cite journal |url= |title=High incidence of obesity co-morbidities in young children: A cross sectional study |last=Bell, Curran, Bryne, Roby, Surinano, Jones & Davis. |date=2011 |journal=Journal of Paediatrics and Child Health |doi=10.1111/j.1440-1754.2011.02102 |pmid=|access-date =}}</ref>
The implementation of public health interventions in child care services has been recommended in Australia as a key strategy in the prevention of children becoming overweight or obese, especially in rural and remote areas of Australia. Quantifying the prevalence of obesity among children attending child care from non-metropolitan areas throughout Australia may be particularly important as the access to obesity prevention resources and professional development opportunities for child care service staff is limited. Financial constraints often experienced by smaller rural and remote child care services may limit their capacity to promote and encourage physical activity and health care to children participating in the child care services provided to them.
The study conducted by Wolfenden et al. found that approximately 17% of all children and 25% of indigenous children attending rural and regional child care services in the study area were overweight or obese.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Wolfenden |first1=Luke |last2=Hardy |first2=Louise L. |last3=Wiggers |first3=John |last4=Milat |first4=Andrew J. |last5=Bell |first5=Colin |last6=Sutherland |first6=Rachel |date=March 2011 |title=Prevalence and socio-demographic associations of overweight and obesity among children attending child care services in rural and regional Australia |work=Nutrition and Dietetics |volume=68 |issue=1 |pages=15–20 |doi=10.1111/j.1747-0080.2010.01487.x}}</ref> Such prevalence rates remain unacceptably high and confirm the need of prevention interventions targeting obesity in this setting.
For childhood obesity, the influence of broader parental and community contexts needs to be considered. Studies have found that young overweight boys spent significantly less time away from their parents than non-overweight boys, this potentially relates to the socio-economic status of the parents, as children residing from parents with a lower education level are at a higher risk of suffering from being overweight.<ref>{{Cite journal |url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com.ipacez.nd.edu.au/doi/10.1111/j.1440-1754.2011.02181.x/abstract |title=Socio-economic, familial and perinatal factors associated with obesity in Sydney schoolchildren |last=gopinath baur burlutsky robaei mitchell |first=bamini louise george dana paul |date=January 2012 |journal=Journal of Paediatrics and Child Health |doi=10.1111/j.1440-1754.2011.02181.x |pmid=|access-date = |issue=1 |volume=48 |pages=44–51}}</ref> It is possible that this is because young boys that spent a lot of their time with their parents were more likely to participate in sedentary activities, such as watching television or playing video games, than they were to participate in any kind of physical activity.
Jones et al. (2010) study found that early school years may be the time when child, parent and community characteristics begin to differ between overweight and non-overweight children, and may be an ideal time to target broader parental and community contexts influencing overweight and obese children.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Jones |first1=RA |last2=Okely |first2=AD |last3=Caputi |first3=P |last4=Cliff |first4=DP |date=May 2010 |title=Relationships between child, parent and community characteristics and weight status among young children |work=International Journal of Pediatric Obesity |volume=5 |issue=3 |pages=256–264 |pmid=19900149 |doi=10.3109/17477160903271971}}</ref>
A recent study conducted by The Swiss School of Public Health in 2014, found a clear association between the prevalence of obesity in low socio-economic standing school children within Australia. In 2006, it was found that children of low socio-economic standing were 2.22 times more likely to be obese compared to their high socio-economic standing counterparts. It was also discovered that these children of low socio-economic standing were 2.20 times more likely to be obese in 2012.<ref>{{Cite journal |url= |title=Prevalence of obesity, overweight and thinness in Australian children and adolescents by socioeconomic status and ethnic cultural group in 2006 and 2012 |date=5 September 2014 |journal=International Journal of Public Health |doi= |pmid=|access-date =}}</ref>
==Diabetes and cost of obesity==
In May 2008, [[Diabetes Australia]], the national body for diabetes awareness and prevention, told the [[Australian House of Representatives|House of Representatives]] that the cost of obesity on the country's health system in 2005 was an estimated [[Australian dollar|A$]]25 billion (US$20 billion),<ref name="abc">{{cite web |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2008/05/12/2242348.htm |title=Obesity costing Australia billions |accessdate=5 July 2009 |date=12 May 2008 |work= |publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation}}</ref> In August 2008, Diabetes Australia's estimation more than doubled to $58 billion ($46 billion USD), this time taking into account not just health care but job productivity and other related quality of living costs.<ref name="australian">{{cite web |url=http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0,25197,24221719-5013404,00.html |title=Girth by sea: obesity costs Australia $58 billion a year |accessdate=5 July 2009 |author=Siobhain Ryan |date=22 August 2008 |work= |publisher=The Australian}}</ref>
In 2003, the number of Australians with [[type 2 diabetes]] rose to nearly a million for the first time.<ref name="theage" /> In addition, the number of type 2 diabetes patients who were diagnosed solely on their weight was calculated at 242,000 in 2007, a 137% increase in cases in the previous three years.<ref name="australian" />
In 2008 using the Body Mass Index scale, obese Australians (indirectly and directly) cost the nation $8.3 billion. Out of the $8.3 billion, $2.0 billion was the cost of the health system.<ref>{{Cite journal |title=The Cost of overweight and obesity in Australia |first1=Stephen |last1=Colagiuri |first2=Crystal M Y |last2=Lee |first3=Ruth |last3=Colagiuri |first4=Dianna |last4=Magliano |first5=Jonathan E |last5=Shaw |first6=Paul Z |last6=Zimmet |first7=Ian D |last7=Caterson |display-authors=3 |date=1 March 2010 |journal=Medical Journal of Australia |doi= |accessdate=31 March 2015 |issue=5 |volume=192 |pages=260–4 |pmid=20201759 |url=https://www.mja.com.au/system/files/issues/192_05_010310/col10841_fm.pdf}}</ref>
==Government response== In April 2008, the [[Government of Australia|Australian Federal Government]] added obesity to its list of "national health priorities", officially elevating it to the same standard of attention given to other deadly ailments such as [[cancer]], [[heart disease]] and [[diabetes]].<ref name="australian2" /> On 1 June 2009, the first Parliamentary comment on obesity in Australia was published, with the Standing Committee on Health and Ageing recommending 20 acts for the Federal Government to consider, including tax incentives to make healthier fruits and vegetables more affordable for Australians, and pressing the government to work with the food industry to lower fat and sugar levels in existing processed food.<ref name="parliament2">{{cite report |url=https://www.nhmrc.gov.au/health-topics/obesity-and-overweight |title=Obesity in Australia Report - "Weighing It Up" }}</ref> These recommendations covered a range of issues affecting obesity in Australia. The government agreed to the majority of the recommendations including to continue supporting the Active After-School communities program which lead more children to have more positive attitude towards physical activity and agreeing to develop consistent urban planning guidelines that focus on creating environments that encourage Australians to be healthy and active.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.health.gov.au/internet/main/publishing.nsf/Content/govt-response-obesity |title=Australian Government response to the House of Representatives standing committee on health and ageing report: weighing it up: obesity in Australia. |date=2013 |accessdate= |website= |publisher=}}</ref>
The former [[Australian Labor Party|ALP]] government under Prime Minister [[Julia Gillard]] wanted to tackle the obesity problem in Australia by giving tax subsidies which would fund gym memberships to people who wish to lose weight.<ref name="telegraph">{{cite news |url=http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/lifestyle/news/subsidies-for-people-to-lose-weight-and-get-fit/story-e6frf00r-1225739827730 |title=Subsidies for people to lose weight and get fit |accessdate=5 July 2009 |author1=Sue Dunlevy |author2=Xanthe Kleinig |lastauthoramp=yes |date=25 June 2009 |work= |publisher=The Daily Telegraph}}</ref> Her watchdog group, the National Preventative Health Taskforce, also wants to target childhood obesity by banning ads for junk food during the daytime when most children's television programs air.<ref name="telegraph" />
In August 2008, the government of [[New South Wales]] announced that it would pay for morbidly obese patients to receive weight loss surgery, the first state to make such an announcement.<ref name="smh">{{cite news |url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/health/state-to-pay-for-obesity-surgery/2008/08/02/1217097606084.html |title=State to pay for obesity surgery |accessdate=5 July 2009 |author=Louise Hall |date=3 August 2008 |work= |publisher=Sydney Morning Herald}}</ref> Most Australians who wish to have such surgery have to go to a private hospital and pay for the procedure themselves, which costs $10,000 ($10,000 USD).<ref name="smh" /> A survey in [[Western Australia]] suggests that the number of patients who have undergone weight loss surgery has increased 20-fold in the past 20 years, with nine out of ten patients opting for the [[lap band]] procedure.<ref name="theage2">{{cite web |url=http://news.theage.com.au/national/obesity-surgery-numbers-skyrocket-study-20080817-3wwt.html |title=Obesity surgery numbers skyrocket: study |accessdate=5 July 2009 |date=17 August 2008 |work= |publisher=The Age}}</ref>
According to The Obesity Society Australia, if obesity rates continue to grow in Australia at this current rate over the next few decades, it is conceivable that the health and economic cost due to obesity will also grow to overwhelming portions.<ref>{{Cite journal |title=To Time to Weight |date=March 2014 |journal=Obesity: A National Epidemic and its Impact on Australia |doi= |pmid= |url=http://www.obesityaustralia.org/resources-1/no-time-to-weight |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160131074140/http://www.obesityaustralia.org/resources-1/no-time-to-weight |archivedate=31 January 2016 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
== See also == {{Portal|Australia|Health}} * [[Australian paradox]] * [[Cardiovascular disease in Australia]] * [[Diabetes in Australia]]
'''General:''' * [[Health in Australia]] * [[Epidemiology of obesity]]

{{more footnotes|date=February 2018}} {{Infobox civilian attack |title=Oregon Museum Tavern Shooting |location= [[Salem, Oregon]], U.S. |target=Oregon Museum Tavern |coordinates = |date=May 7, 1981 |time= 10:30pm |type=[[Mass murder]], [[Spree killer|shooting spree]] |fatalities=5 |injuries=18 |perp=Lawrence William Moore |weapons= [[9mm]] [[Browning Hi-Power|Browning HP]] handgun }}
The '''Oregon Museum Tavern Shooting''' occurred on May 7, 1981, at Oregon Museum Tavern in [[Salem, Oregon]].
== Incident == Lawrence William Moore, 25, of [[Scio, Oregon]], an unemployed mill worker walked into the crowded Oregon Museum Tavern on Front Street NE which was hosting a [[Ladies' night]] and without saying a word started to fire his 9mm Browning handgun.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://kval.com/news/local/32-years-later-oregon-bar-shooting-victim-dies|title=32 years later, Oregon bar shooting victim dies|first=JOCE DEWITT, Salem Statesman|last=Journal|publisher=}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/09/us/four-slain-and-20-wounded-in-bar-as-oregon-man-shoots-into-crowd.html|title=FOUR SLAIN AND 20 WOUNDED IN BAR AS OREGON MAN SHOOTS INTO CROWD|first=|last=AP|publisher=}}</ref> <ref name=":0">{{cite web|url=https://www.upi.com/Archives/1981/10/16/Conviction-on-4-counts-of-murder-for-man-who-shot-up-bar/8478372052800/|title=Conviction on 4 counts of murder for man who shot up bar|publisher=}}</ref> Moore first fired at the bar, before turning the weapon at patrons who began to flee.<ref name=":0" />
Once the magazine had run out he reloaded and continued firing.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://katu.com/news/local/30-years-later-sounds-of-gunfire-still-haunt-shooting-victim|title=30 years later, sounds of gunfire still haunt shooting victim|first=Bob Heye, KATU On Your Side Investigator and KATU.com|last=Staff|publisher=}}</ref> One of the times he was reloading several patrons at the tavern overpowered him, wrestled him to ground and held him waiting of the police to arrive.
The killing spree ended with the killing 3 people at the scene and injuring 20 others; one of these died in hospital later that night, and Dennis Scharf died nearly 32 years later from injuries sustained.
== Fatalities == *Lori J. Cunningham, 22 – died at the scene *John W. Cooper, 27 – died at the scene *Robert E. Hamblin, 24 – died at the scene *Allen L. Wilcox, 24 – died at hospital *Dennis Scharf – died January 19, 2013 due to complications from injuries sustained
== Legal and aftermath == At trial, beginning on October 6, 1981, he pleaded innocent to the murder charges, citing mental disease or defect as a defense; however, he admitted to being the gunman. Moore stated the reason for the shooting that he was trying to get members of a 'syndicate' of millionaires, Jews and criminals who had been trying to poison him.
Moore was subsequently found guilty of four counts of aggravated murder and sentenced to four life terms in prison.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://law.justia.com/cases/texas/third-court-of-appeals/1997/1301.html|title=Lawrence William Moore v. The State of Texas--Appeal from 331st District Court of Travis County|work=Justia Law|access-date=2018-09-24|language=en}}</ref>
=== Memorial === The names of the deceased victims are included in a joint memorial wall at [[Oregon City, Oregon|Oregon City's]] Mountain View Cemetery that memorializes some 390 people that were murdered. The memorial was dedicated by The Greater Portland Area Chapter of [[Parents of Murdered Children Memorial|Parents of Murdered Children]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.oregonlive.com/oregon-city/index.ssf/2013/09/oregon_city_memorial_gives_lov.html|title=Loved ones find comfort in Oregon City memorial to homicide victims (photo gallery)|work=OregonLive.com|access-date=2018-09-24|language=en-US}}</ref>
==See also== *[[List of massacres in the United States]] *[[List of rampage killers (Americas)]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=October 2017}} {{Use American English|date=June 2017}} {{Infobox civilian attack | title = Orlando factory shooting | partof = | image = | alt = | caption = | map = | map_alt = | map_caption = | location = [[Orlando, Florida]], U.S. | target = Employees of Fiamma | coordinates = | date = June 5, 2017 | time = | timezone = | type = [[Mass shooting]] | fatalities = 6 (including the perpetrator) | injuries = | perp = John Robert Neumann Jr. | motive = Currently unknown | weapons = Handgun, knives | numparts = <!-- or | numpart = --> | dfens = <!-- or | dfen = --> | website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> }}
On June 5, 2017, John Robert Neumann Jr., a 45-year-old former employee of Fiamma, killed five former colleagues and himself.<ref name=cbs-news-friend-orlando-victim-feared-workplace-shooter-would-seek-revenge-over-shooting>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/friend-orlando-victim-feared-workplace-shooter-would-seek-revenge-over-firing/|title=Friend: Orlando victim feared workplace shooter would seek revenge over firing|publisher=[[CBS News]]|date=June 6, 2017|accessdate=June 6, 2017}}</ref><ref name=orlando-sentinel-orlando-workplace-shooting>{{cite news|url=http://www.orlandosentinel.com/news/orlando-workplace-shooting/os-orlando-workplace-shooting-20170605-story.html|title=Orlando workplace shooting: Former employee kills 5, then himself|publisher=[[Orlando Sentinel]]|last1=Harris|first1=David|last2=Hayes|first2=Christal|last3=Williams|first3=Michael|date=June 5, 2017|accessdate=June 6, 2017}}</ref> [[Orange County, Florida|Orange County]] Sheriff Jerry Demings said Neumann did not appear to belong to any kind of subversive or terrorist group.<ref name=cbs-news-friend-orlando-victim-feared-workplace-shooter-would-seek-revenge-over-shooting/>
==Shooting== John Robert Neumann Jr. let himself into the building through a rear entrance and was armed with a handgun and a large hunting knife.<ref name=orlando-sentinel-orlando-workplace-shooting/> He singled out his five victims and shot them in their heads. He then fatally shot himself as deputies responded to the scene.<ref name=cbs-news-friend-orlando-victim-feared-workplace-shooter-would-seek-revenge-over-shooting/><ref name=orlando-sentinel-orlando-workplace-shooting/> Eight other employees who worked at the company and were present during the shooting escaped without injury.<ref name=orlando-sentinel-orlando-workplace-shooting/>
The shooting occurred nearly one year after another [[2016 Orlando nightclub shooting|mass shooting in the same city]], which had been the deadliest mass shooting in U.S. history at the time.<ref>http://www.cnn.com/2017/06/05/us/orlando-fatalities/index.html</ref>
==Victims== The five victims were Robert Snyder, 69, lead manager at the factory; Brenda Montanez-Crespo, 44; Kevin Clark, 53; Jeffrey Roberts, 57; and Kevin Lawson, 46.<ref name=cbs-news-friend-orlando-victim-feared-workplace-shooter-would-seek-revenge-over-shooting/><ref name=orlando-sentinel-orlando-workplace-shooting/> A local youth sports league raised money for the children of Kevin Clark, who were [[orphaned]], as their mother had died nine years earlier.<ref name=cbs-news-friend-orlando-victim-feared-workplace-shooter-would-seek-revenge-over-shooting/><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.torontosun.com/2017/06/05/multiple-fatalities-after-industrial-area-shooting-in-orlando |publisher=''[[The Toronto Sun]]'' |agency=[[The Associated Press]] |title=Orlando factory shooting orphans 2 teens |date=June 6, 2017 |accessdate=June 7, 2017}}</ref>
==Perpetrator== John Robert Neumann Jr. (1971 – June 5, 2017) received an honorable discharge from the [[United States Army|U.S. Army]] in 1999.<ref name=cbs-news-friend-orlando-victim-feared-workplace-shooter-would-seek-revenge-over-shooting/> He did not have a concealed weapons permit.<ref name=cbs-news-friend-orlando-victim-feared-workplace-shooter-would-seek-revenge-over-shooting/> He had a history of minor crimes before the shooting, mostly associated with traffic.<ref name=cbs-news-friend-orlando-victim-feared-workplace-shooter-would-seek-revenge-over-shooting/>
Neumann once worked for Fiamma, which made awnings for [[recreational vehicle]]s and [[campervan]]s. He was fired in April 2017 for starting fights with people.<ref name=cbs-news-friend-orlando-victim-feared-workplace-shooter-would-seek-revenge-over-shooting/> The lead manager who fired him later feared he would return for revenge.<ref name=cbs-news-friend-orlando-victim-feared-workplace-shooter-would-seek-revenge-over-shooting/><ref name=orlando-sentinel-orlando-workplace-shooting/> Police dealt with him in 2014 when he was accused of battering a coworker at the factory.<ref name=cbs-news-friend-orlando-victim-feared-workplace-shooter-would-seek-revenge-over-shooting/><ref name=orlando-sentinel-orlando-workplace-shooting/>
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{Refimprove|date=June 2017}} [[File:PWA - Patients' Welfare Association logo.JPG|thumb|Patients' Welfare Association's Logo]] The '''Patients' Welfare Association''' ('''PWA''') is a non-political, non-governmental organization (NGO) located within [[Civil Hospital]], [[Karachi]] run by the students of [[Dow Medical College]], which works for the medical aid of underprivileged patients by providing a number of services free of charge. The organization depends upon its donors and volunteers for its functionality and maintenance. Other than conventional charity donations and [[zakat]] funds the PWA also holds many fund raising campaigns such as bake sales and promotion in school campuses.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pwa-chk.org |title=アコムでお金を借りる！【即日審査、振込…どうすれば可能？】 |website=Pwa-chk.org |date= |accessdate=2017-06-15}}</ref><ref name="autogenerated2005">{{cite web|url=http://www.dawn.com/2005/07/06/local9.htm |title=KARACHI: ‘Bake Sale Mela’ held at CHK - Newspaper |website=Dawn.com |date=2005-07-06 |accessdate=2017-06-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thenews.com.pk/print1.asp?id=131875 |title=The News International: Latest News Breaking, Pakistan News |website=Thenews.com.pk |date=2017-06-09 |accessdate=2017-06-15}}</ref> Established in 1979, by three students of [[Dow Medical College]],<ref name="autogenerated2005"/><ref name="pwa-chk1">{{cite web |url=http://www.pwa-chk.org/drug%20bank.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-12-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090608003359/http://www.pwa-chk.org/drug%20bank.html |archivedate=2009-06-08 |df= }}</ref> it soon transformed from being a small student based organization to a much larger movement with much coverage of their humanitarian deeds being publicized by means of local Television channels, Newspaper,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dawn.com/2008/08/15/local4.htm |title=KARACHI: Health dept wants extra funds: Dengue fever - Newspaper |website=Dawn.com |date=2008-08-15 |accessdate=2017-06-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thenews.com.pk/daily_detail.asp?id=112518 |title=The News International: Latest News Breaking, Pakistan News |website=Thenews.com.pk |date=2017-06-09 |accessdate=2017-06-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dawn.com/news/880730 |title=Volunteers at college |website=Dawn.com |date=2009-11-22 |accessdate=2017-06-15}}</ref> Radio as well as their own newsletter which is circulated in their locality.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.pwa-chk.org/QASID2005_2.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-12-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303205435/http://www.pwa-chk.org/QASID2005_2.html |archivedate=2016-03-03 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/pwachk |title=Patients' Welfare Association-PWA - Home |publisher=[[Facebook]] |date= |accessdate=2017-06-15}}</ref>
==History== Patients' Welfare Association was established as a small student based organization by three students of [[Dow Medical College]] in 1979,<ref name="autogenerated2005"/><ref name="pwa-chk1"/> with simple services such as free of cost drugs for needy patients. In the years to come the organization gained much popularity and by 1982 it had gained enough funds and volunteer force to form a blood bank and a [[Thalassemia]] Follow-up Clinic.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.pwa-chk.org/blood%20bank.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-12-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090606093710/http://www.pwa-chk.org/blood%20bank.html |archivedate=2009-06-06 |df= }}</ref><ref>[http://www.pwa-chk.org/QASID2005_3.html ]{{dead link|date=June 2017}}</ref> With their influence spreading, in 1986 a diagnostic laboratory was set up.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.pwa-chk.org/diagnostic%20lab.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-12-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090608003353/http://www.pwa-chk.org/diagnostic%20lab.html |archivedate=2009-06-08 |df= }}</ref><ref name="pwa-chk2">{{cite web |url=http://www.pwa-chk.org/QASID2005_1.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-12-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090107061120/http://www.pwa-chk.org/QASID2005_1.html |archivedate=2009-01-07 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dawn.com/2002/06/27/local12.htm |title=KARACHI: PWA generates funds for poor patients : Fund-raising bake sale today - Newspaper |website=Dawn.com |date=2002-06-27 |accessdate=2017-06-15}}</ref>
==Services== With the slogan "''We feel, We serve''," their existence depends on service to the underprivileged segment of society. The organization achieves this by means of several departments which have been built within the vicinity of [[Civil Hospital]], [[Karachi]].
===Blood bank=== The Blood bank provides more than 350 units of blood daily on exchange basis not only to patients of Civil Hospital Karachi, but also extends its services to patients all over the city.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dawn.com/2007/11/06/local5.htm |title=KARACHI: LGH gynae section lacks staff, basic facilities - Newspaper |website=Dawn.com |date=2007-11-06 |accessdate=2017-06-15}}</ref> All units dispatched are screened for [[Hepatitis B]], [[Hepatitis C]], [[HIV]], [[Syphilis]] and Malarial Parasite, thus ensuring patient safety. The blood bank also provides blood components such as packed cells, platelets and fresh frozen plasma.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.pwa-chk.org/bloodbank.php |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-11-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110918135320/http://www.pwa-chk.org/bloodbank.php |archivedate=2011-09-18 |df= }}</ref> The Blood Bank has also started the service of providing mega unit of platelets to patients of Civil Hospital Karachi, free of cost.
===Thalassemia Services=== Previously working under the 'Follow Up Clinics', PWA Thalassemia Services was upgraded to a separate department with the start of transfusion facility for registered Thalassemia patients in 2011. The department has got 260 registered patients suffering from Thalassemia, a hereditary blood disorder. These patients are receiving regular blood transfusions and consultations by a qualified Haematologist along with regular diagnostic investigations, Due to shortage of funds, only 60 registered patients are currently being provided with Iron chelation therapy. efforts are under-way to collect funds and start provision of Iron chelation therapy to all registered patients. The cost of treatment of one patients suffering from this lifelong disease is Pakistani Rs. 300,000 - Rs. 500,000 per annum depending upon the age and blood transfusion needs of the patient. PWA Thalassemia Services is providing all these facilities completely free of charge.
==Other events== The Patients' Welfare Association holds many events; from fund raising activities to seminars concerning local medical issues. One of their main fund raising events is an annual ‘Food Mela', a bake sale of colossal magnitude, where funds more than one million rupees have been gathered in recent years.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dawn.com/2005/07/06/local9.htm |title=KARACHI: ‘Bake Sale Mela’ held at CHK - Newspaper |website=Dawn.com |date=2005-07-06 |accessdate=2017-06-15}}</ref><ref name="pwa-chk2"/>
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
[[Category:Organisations based in Karachi]] [[Category:Medical and health organisations based in Pakistan]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2013}} {{Infobox organization | name = Radiation Effects Research Foundation | native_name = | native_name_lang = | named_after = | image = RERF_Logo.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = | logo = | abbreviation = RERF | motto = | predecessor = [[Atomic Bomb Casualty Commission]] | merged = | successor = | formation = {{end date and age|1975|04|01}} | founder = | founding_location = [[Hiroshima]], [[Japan]] | extinction = | merger = | leader_name = Dr. Ohtsura Niwa }}'''The Radiation Effects Research Foundation (RERF)''' is a joint U.S.-Japan research organization responsible for studying the medical effects of radiation and associated diseases in humans for the welfare of the survivors and all humankind.<ref name=":0">Introduction to Radiation Effects Research Foundation. (1995). Radiation Effects Research Foundation, pp.1-3. Available at: <nowiki>http://rerf.jp/shared/introd/introRERFe.pdf</nowiki> [Accessed 26 Feb. 2018].</ref> The organization is located in Hiroshima, Japan.
The studies have been going on for 70 years, which makes RERF the only institution that has been conducting epidemiological studies on a population of more than 120,000 individuals for this long.<ref name=":1">A Brief Description. (2014). Radiation Effects Research Foundation, p.1. Available at: <nowiki>http://rerf.jp/shared/briefdescript/briefdescript_e.pdf</nowiki> [Accessed 26 Feb. 2018].</ref> RERF continues to conduct research until this day because the effects of A-bomb radiation on human health have not been fully elucidated.<ref name=":0" />
RERF conducts research in multiple fields of science including epidemiology, clinical medicine, genetics, and immunology.<ref name=":1" /> Findings from RERF’s studies have been used not only for the medical care and welfare of the A-bomb survivors but also for the establishment of international radiation protection standards.<ref name=":1" />
== History == The preceding organization to RERF was the Atomic Bomb Casualty Commission which was established in 1948 by the U.S National Academy of Sciences.<ref name=":1" /> It was established to determine how, over long-term, exposure to radiation affected the health of A-bomb survivors.<ref name=":0" />
An extensive interview survey was conducted in the 1950s, based on which records were compiled for each A-bomb survivor.<ref name=":0" /> These records concerned location and structure of the building the survivor may have been at the time of the bombing. Based on these records, radiation doses were calculated for most A-bomb survivors.<ref name=":0" />
RERF was established on April 1, 1975, as a nonprofit foundation under the jurisdiction of the Japan Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Ministry of Health and Welfare.<ref name=":0" /> On April 1, 2012, RERF transitioned to a public interest incorporated foundation upon authorization by Japan’s Prime Minister.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://mothra.rerf.or.jp/|title=Radiation Effects Research Foundation|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref>
== Research Programs<ref name=":2" /> == RERF studies the effects of radiation on the survivors of the atomic bombings in Japan.
=== Life Span Study === This study gathers samples from the general population of both sexes and all ages. It is the most informative epidemiological study in the world, because of its long duration. It provides information about cancer incidence, cancer mortality and non-cancer effects on the survivors. RERF wants to continue the studies for complete lifetimes of the participants.
=== Adult Health Study === This is a clinical study of a sub-cohort of the Life Span Study, conducted every two years. It is investigating age and radiation-related physiological changes.
=== Children of Atomic-bomb Survivors Study === The study’s goal is to determine whether genetic effects may appear in the children of the atomic bomb survivors. RERF has observed no radiation effects in the study of birth defects, chromosome abnormalities, and serum proteins. Currently, molecular studies on DNA are being conducted.
=== In Utero Study === This study investigates the effects of radiation on the people who were in utero at the time of the bombing (about 3,600 persons).
=== Radiation Biology === Radiation biology studies seek to understand the result of physical phenomena involved in radiation response. The studies are directed to DNA indications that cause breast and thyroid cancer.
=== Immunology === This study focuses on the changes in the immune system of people exposed to atomic-bomb radiation.
=== Molecular Epidemiology === This is a newly emerging field of study at RERF, which investigates the radiation effects by looking at molecular changes in DNA. It is used to understand the mechanisms and causes of disease better.
=== Cytogenetics === Cytogenetics helps assess radiation exposure (biological dosimetry) by evaluating the structural damage in chromosomes.
=== Statistics === This study assesses the risks through the application of mathematical models to rates of disease occurrence or death to identify radiation effects. The statisticians also take part in other studies done at RERF to develop better methods for analysis of data.
=== Atomic-bomb Dosimetry === This study provides survivors with radiation exposure dose estimates, based on the knowledge of physics and sensitive measurements that detect minute traces of the atomic bomb radiation in various materials. The information is also combined with historical interview data.
== Facilities == RERF has 2 facilities: one based in Hiroshima and one in Nagasaki.<ref name=":2" />
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.rerf.or.jp Radiation Effects Research Foundation] Home website in English and Japanese
[[Category:Atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki]] [[Category:Radiation health effects researchers|*]] [[Category:1975 establishments in Japan]]
