revision.text:
{{Infobox scientist |name = Raymond Pearl |image = Dr. Raymond Pearl, Food. Adm. LCCN2016824384 (cropped).jpg |image_size = |caption = |birth_date = {{birth date|1879|06|03}} |birth_place =[[Farmington, New Hampshire]] |death_date = {{death date and age|1940|11|17|1879|06|03}} |death_place =[[Baltimore, Maryland]] |residence = |citizenship = |nationality = [[United States|American]] |ethnicity = |field = [[Biogerontology]] |work_institutions = [[Johns Hopkins University]] |alma_mater = [[University of Michigan]] |doctoral_advisor = |doctoral_students = |known_for = |author_abbrev_bot = Pearl |author_abbrev_zoo = |influences = |influenced = |prizes = |religion = |footnotes = |signature = }} '''Raymond Pearl''' (3 June 1879 – 17 November 1940) was an American [[biologist]], regarded as one of the founders of [[biogerontology]]. He spent most of his career at [[Johns Hopkins University]] in [[Baltimore]]. Pearl was a prolific writer of academic books, papers and articles, as well as a committed populariser and communicator of [[science]]. At his death, 841 publications were listed against his name.
==Early life==
Pearl was born into an upper-middle class in [[Farmington, New Hampshire]] on June 3, 1879. At an early age, Pearl was exposed to the classics. His parents and grandparents wanted him to study Greek and Latin. However, when he attended [[Dartmouth College]] at 16 years old, he became fascinated by biology and graduated with a B.A. as the youngest in his class. At Dartmouth, he was known to be an exceptional student as well as a skilled musician. He was capable of playing almost every wind instrument, and he planned amateur music performances with his friends and colleagues. In 1899, Pearl attended the [[University of Michigan]] where he received his PhD in [[zoology]] for his work on the behavior of planarians. He also was involved in studying the variation of fish for the Biological Survey of the [[Great Lakes]]. While working in a zoological laboratory, he met his future wife, Maude M. De Witt. In 1903, they married, and together in 1905 and 1906, they traveled abroad and worked at the [[University of London]], [[University of Leipzig]], and Marine Biological Station in Naples.<ref name=Goldman>{{cite journal|last1=Goldman|first1=I.L.|title=Raymond Pearl, smoking and longevity|journal=Genetics|date=November 1, 2002|volume=162|issue=3|pages=997–1001|url=http://www.genetics.org/content/162/3/997.short|pmid=12454050|pmc=1462343}}</ref>
In 1906, he spent a year studying under [[Karl Pearson]] at University College, London. During this year he discovered [[biometry]], which seemed to offer a solution to the problems he was concerned with in biology, zoology and [[eugenics]]. On his return to the US he continued his interests, but was converted from biometry to [[Mendelian genetics]].
==Career==
Pearl’s interest in statistical methods in biology began at the University of London, where he worked alongside Karl Pearson. He stayed as an instructor at the University of Michigan until 1906, and that same year, he went to the [[University of Pennsylvania]] to be an instructor in zoology. A year later, he became the head of the Department of Biology of the Main Agricultural Experiment Station at the [[University of Maine]] in Orono where he studied the genetics of poultry and other domestic animals. From 1917 to 1919, Pearl was the Chief of the Statistical Division of the [[United States Food Administration]]. In 1918, Pearl developed a department of laboratory statistics when he was recruited by Johns Hopkins University to be the Professor of Biometry and Vital Statistics.<ref name=Goldman />
In 1920 he was elected as a [[Fellow]] of the [[American Statistical Association]],<ref>[http://www.amstat.org/awards/fellowslist.cfm List of ASA Fellows], retrieved 2016-07-16.</ref> which he also served as president.
==Wilson's attack==
In 1929, Pearl’s friend [[William Morton Wheeler]] was about to retire as the Dean of the Bussey Institution at [[Harvard University]]. At this time, there were plans to alter the current biological departments and create a field of human biology at Harvard. Due to his connections at Harvard, Pearl was mentioned as a possible candidate to succeed Wheeler and had many supporters there. However, [[Edwin Bidwell Wilson]], a Harvard mathematician, was a critic of Pearl and did not believe he was fit for this position. Wilson believed that great detail and attention should be used when dealing with the math of biological data and thought that Pearl had been messy with his handling and reasoning of math in the field of biology. Wilson’s first issue with Pearl was his study of population growth in the 1920s. Pearl stated that he discovered the law of population that represented an S-shaped curve of growth, but Wilson thought that his data was insufficient and did not support this assertion.<ref name=Kingsland>{{cite journal|last1=Kingsland|first1=Sharon|title=Raymond Pearl: On the Frontier in the 1920's: Raymond Pearl Memorial Lecture, 1983|journal=Human Biology|date=February 1984|volume=56|issue=1|pages=1–18|jstor=41463546|pmid=6378756}}</ref>
Despite his criticism of Pearl, in 1925, Wilson reached out to Pearl for help on his cancer research. Pearl was unaware of Wilson’s criticism of him at the time. He did not help Wilson because he thought that he did not have a sufficient understanding of the biological and medical fields, which further ignited Wilson's distaste of Pearl. In 1929, Pearl conducted research on the correlation between tuberculosis and cancer and published a paper that claimed that there is a negative correlation. This research had mistakes in its data analysis, so Wilson saw this study as an opportunity to attack Pearl and prevent him from becoming the new dean. Wilson denounced Pearl’s use of mathematics in the cancer study to different departments at Harvard and published about it as well. His efforts paid off as the Board of Overseers at Harvard rejected Pearl’s nomination by a vote of ten to nine. Pearl continued his scientific pursuits at Hopkins until his death.<ref name=Kingsland />
==Eugenics, medicine, and politics==
Pearl was a eugenicist who held traditional [[Francis Galton|Galtonian]] beliefs. He wanted to use eugenics and biometry in medicine and public health in order to gain knowledge of human heredity.<ref name=Comfort>{{cite book|last1=Comfort|first1=Nathaniel|title=The Science of Human Perfection: How Genes Became the Heart of American Medicine|date=2012|publisher=Yale University Press|location=New Haven & London|pages=67–96}}</ref>
Pearl founded the Constitutional Clinic at the [[Johns Hopkins Hospital]]. He believed in constitutional medicine, which focuses on examining the soil on which a seed falls. He later became the director of a new Institute of Biological Research at Johns Hopkins in 1925 that was aimed at examining the genetics and environmental factors of disease. This research institute combined biometry, genetics, and medicine to investigate the hereditary predisposition of [[tuberculosis]] and [[hypertension]]. When conducting his research of these diseases, Pearl recorded the height, weight, handedness, measurements of different body parts, and physical descriptions. Just like Galton, he believed that race was an important factor in human characteristics and believed in using biology and genetics to improve the long-term health of the population. Although he tried to be quantitative, objective, and systematic, his classifications of different races were influenced by social norms and prejudices.<ref name=Comfort />
However, in the late 1920s, Pearl condemned eugenics. Pearl criticized the use of race in eugenics despite conducting research that recognized racial differences. He believed that eugenics was doing the right thing badly and that human biology was eugenics done right if it consisted of reliable statistics, objectivity, a liberal social agenda, and medical affiliations.<ref name=Comfort/> In 1927, he published the landmark article ''The Biology of Superiority'', which attacked the basic assumptions of eugenics.<ref>{{Cite journal | volume = 12 | pages = 257–266 | last = Pearl | first = Raymond | title = The biology of superiority | journal = American Mercury | year = 1927 }}</ref> The article was the first general attack on eugenics by someone perceived as being within the movement.<ref name=allan>{{Cite book | publisher = Cambridge University Press | isbn = 978-0-521-27560-6 | pages = 169‒202 | editors = Hugo Tristram Engelhardt and Arthur Leonard Caplan (eds.) | last = Allen | first = Garland E. | title = Scientific controversies: case studies in the resolution and closure of disputes in science and technology | chapter = The role of experts in scientific controversy | location = Cambridge ; New York | year = 1987 }}</ref> It also contributed to the emergence of reform eugenics and the [[population control]] movement. Pearl was an influential member of the Advisory Committee of the [[World Population Conference]],<ref>{{cite book|last=Sanger|first=Margaret|title=Proceedings of the World Population Conference|year=1927|publisher=Edward Arnold & Co.|location=London|page=11|url=https://books.google.com/?id=MyRBAAAAIAAJ&q=%22proceedings+of+the+world+population+conference%22&dq=%22proceedings+of+the+world+population+conference%22}}</ref> after which Pearl helped found the [[International Union for the Scientific Study of Population Problems]].<ref name="allan" /><ref name=ludmerer >{{Cite journal | last1 = Ludmerer | first1 = K. M. | title = American geneticists and the eugenics movement: 1905–1935 | doi = 10.1007/BF00125023 | journal = Journal of the History of Biology | volume = 2 | issue = 2 | pages = 337–362 | year = 1969 | pmid = | pmc = }}</ref>
Despite his apparent rejection of eugenics, Pearl maintained relatively good relations with key eugenicists<ref>{{Cite book | publisher = Oxford University Press | isbn = 978-0-19-534878-1 | last = Kühl | first = Stefan | title = The Nazi Connection: Eugenics, American Racism, and German National Socialism | location = Oxford | date = 2002-02-14 }}</ref> and expressed classist views.<ref>{{Cite book | publisher = U of Minnesota Press | isbn = 978-0-8166-3558-0 | last = Ordover | first = Nancy | title = American Eugenics: Race, Queer Anatomy, and the Science of Nationalism | year = 2003 | page = 146}}</ref> He made statements which have been interpreted as being [[anti-Semitic]].<ref>{{Cite book | publisher = Cambridge University Press | isbn = 978-0-521-45875-7 | last = Barkan | first = Elazar | title = The Retreat of Scientific Racism: Changing Concepts of Race in Britain and the United States Between the World Wars | date = 1993-09-16 | page = 216 }}</ref> From 1927-1932, Pearl and his colleague Alan Meyer were important figures of one of the first birth control clinics in the United States called Baltimore’s Bureau for Contraceptive Advice. Pearl was a supporter of birth control, but had a more conservative and scientific approach when compared to the ideologies of [[Margaret Sanger]]. The clinic performed a eugenic medicine study that looked at how the distribution of birth control information that was provided by a clinic affected society.<ref name=Comfort/>
==Scientific interests==
Pearl's main focus of interest was in biostatistics. As one of the first biostatisticians to use mathematics as a way to interpret population genetics, Pearl published a book called ''Modes of Research in Genetics'' in 1915 and another book called ''Introduction to Medical Biometry and Statistics'' in 1923. They were both widely read and were influential in showing the importance of statistics in the genetic and medical fields.<ref name=Goldman />
Even though many of his books were well-received, some of his beliefs still caused controversy. One such belief was that when a brother and sister reproduce, there would not be an increase in homozygosity. Pearl believed that with brother-sister breeding and no selection past the F3 generation, heterozygosity would not fall below 50%.<ref name=Goldman />
Even though his main interest was biostatistics, Pearl had a wide range of interests in biology and was known for his broad knowledge of the subject. He published works on animal behavior, population growth, food and prices, Jewish and Christian marriages, and vegetarianism. In the 1920s and 1930s, Pearl focused on the effect that the environment, which included disease, alcohol, and tobacco, has on longevity. He published a book called ''Alcohol and Longevity'' in 1926, where he claimed that moderate consumption of alcohol could be beneficial for cardiovascular health, which was met with much debate due to prohibition. Controversy continued when Pearl conducted a study on tobacco in which he demonstrated that smoking decreases longevity while drinking does not.<ref name=Goldman />
Pearl is regarded as one of founders of [[Gerontology#Biogerontology|biogerontology]]. In 1908 Max Rubner observed that mammals of different size and [[longevity]] had equal [[mass]] specific [[metabolism|metabolic]] output.<ref>{{Cite book| first=Max | last=Rubner | year=1908 | title=Das Problem der Lebensdauer und seine Beziehungen zum Wachstum und Ernahrung | publisher=Oldenbourg | location=Munich, Germany}}{{Page needed|date=September 2010}}</ref> Partly based on the observation that the longevity of [[Drosophila melanogaster|fruit flies]] varies inversely with ambient temperature,<ref>{{Cite journal| author=Loeb, Jaques and Northrop,J.H. | title=On the influence of food and temperature upon the duration of life | journal=The Journal of Biological Chemistry | volume=32 | issue=1 | date=1 October 1917| pages=103–121 |url=http://www.jbc.org/cgi/reprint/32/1/103 }}</ref> Pearl (like Rubner) also asserted that [[maximum life span]] is inversely proportional to [[basal metabolic rate]]. Pearl accepted [[Alexis Carrel]]'s erroneous ideas that normal [[somatic cell]]s don't age, and that aging must therefore be due to dysfunction at the body level. Pearl speculated that lifespan was limited by vital cell components that were depleted or damaged more rapidly in animals with faster metabolisms.<ref>{{Cite book| first=Raymond | last=Pearl | year=1928 | title=The Rate of Living, Being an Account of Some Experimental Studies on the Biology of Life Duration | publisher=Alfred A. Knopf | location=New York}}{{Page needed|date=September 2010}}</ref> [[Denham Harman]]'s [[free-radical theory|free-radical theory of aging]] later provided a plausible causal mechanism for Pearl's hypothesis.
The ''Rate of Living Hypothesis'' enjoyed prominence as one of the foremost [[Senescence#Theories of aging|theories of aging]] for nearly 50 years. The ''Rate of Living Hypothesis'' is undermined by the observation that a [[rat]] and a [[bat]] have similar metabolic rate, but a bat lives several times longer.<ref>{{Cite journal|vauthors=Brunet-Rossinni AK, Austad SN |title=Ageing studies on bats: a review |journal=Biogerontology |volume=5 |issue=4 |pages=211–22 |year=2004 |pmid=15314271 |doi=10.1023/B:BGEN.0000038022.65024.d8}}</ref> More recently, further doubts have been raised on the ''Rate of Living Hypothesis'' by the demonstration that, when modern statistical methods for correcting for the effects of body size and phylogeny are employed, metabolic rate does not correlate with longevity in mammals or birds.<ref>{{Cite journal|vauthors=de Magalhães JP, Costa J, Church GM |title=An analysis of the relationship between metabolism, developmental schedules, and longevity using phylogenetic independent contrasts |journal=The Journals of Gerontology. Series A, Biological Sciences and Medical Sciences |volume=62 |issue=2 |pages=149–60 |date=February 2007 |pmid=17339640 |pmc=2288695 |url=http://biomed.gerontologyjournals.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=17339640 |format= |doi=10.1093/gerona/62.2.149 }}{{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> (For a critique of the ''Rate of Living Hypothesis'' see ''Living fast, dying when?''.<ref>{{Cite journal|vauthors=Speakman JR, Selman C, McLaren JS, Harper EJ |title=Living fast, dying when? The link between aging and energetics |journal=The Journal of Nutrition |volume=132 |issue=6 Suppl 2 |pages=1583S–97S |date=June 2002 |pmid=12042467 |url=http://jn.nutrition.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=12042467}}</ref>)
==Social habits and death== Pearl was widely known for his lust for life and his love of food, drink, music and parties.<ref name=kingsland>{{Cite journal | last1 = Kingsland | first1 = S. | title = Raymond Pearl: On the frontier in the 1920's. Raymond Pearl memorial lecture, 1983 | journal = Human Biology | volume = 56 | issue = 1 | pages = 1–18 | year = 1984 | pmid = 6378756 }}</ref> He was a key member of the [[Saturday Night Club]] which also included [[H. L. Mencken]].<ref>{{Cite book | publisher = Oxford University Press | isbn = 978-0-19-983927-8 | last = Rodgers | first = Marion Elizabeth | title = Mencken:The American Iconoclast | date = 2007-09-01 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite book | publisher = Springer New York | isbn = 978-1-4614-3648-5| pages = 129–141 | editors = Alan Agresti (ed.) | last = Meng | first = Xiao-Li | author2 = Charles Rohde| author3 = Scott L. Zeger| author4 = Karen Kruse Thomas| author5 = Karen Bandeen-Roche |author5-link=Karen Bandeen-Roche| title = Strength in Numbers: The Rising of Academic Statistics Departments in the U. S. | chapter = Johns Hopkins University Department of Biostatistics | location = New York, NY | year = 2012 | chapterurl = https://link.springer.com/10.1007/978-1-4614-3649-2_10 }}</ref> [[Prohibition]] made no dent in Pearl's drinking habits (which were legendary).
Raymond Pearl is, also, known for his population biology work, as in his 1928 volume, ''The Rate of Living: Being an Account of Some Experimental Studies on the Biology of Life Duration.'' In this book, he presents extensive research regarding population density effects on life duration in fruit flies, demonstrating that an optimal population density existed for that insect in his experimental model. This raised the question of whether or not the same effect might not occur in other species, including humans. His work demonstrating longer lifespans for flies with lower metabolic rates, also, raised the question of whether or not a similar phenomenon might be found in other species, including humans. Thus, he became a mentor to John B. Calhoun, famous for his ecological studies of rodent populations and their possible importance for modern humans. Population density effects on duration of life is thought, by population biologists, to be Raymond Pearl's greatest contribution to biological science.
In November 1940, Pearl was in apparently good health and paid a visit to the [[Baltimore Zoo]]. He cut his trip short complaining of chest pains and died later that day. {{Clear}} {{botanist|Pearl|Pearl, Raymond}}
==See also== * [[Maximum life span]] * [[Senescence]] (aging theories) * [[Life extension]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==Further reading== *{{Cite journal|author=Goldman IL |title=Raymond Pearl, smoking and longevity |journal=Genetics |volume=162 |issue=3 |pages=997–1001 |date=November 2002 |pmid=12454050 |pmc=1462343 |url=http://www.genetics.org/cgi/content/full/162/3/997}} *{{Cite journal|author=Kingsland S |title=Raymond Pearl: on the frontier in 1920s. Raymond Pearl memorial lecture, 1983 |journal=Human Biology |volume=56 |issue=1 |pages=1–18 |date=February 1984 |pmid=6378756}} *{{Cite journal|author=Lloyd PJ |title=American German and British antecedents to Pearl and Reed's logistic curve |journal=Population Studies |volume=21 |issue= 2|pages=99–109 |year=1967 |pmid=11630390 |doi=10.2307/2172714 |publisher=Population Investigation Committee|jstor=2172714}} *{{Cite journal|author=Alvarez WC |title=Raymond Pearl, student of longevity; 1879-1946 |journal=Geriatrics |volume=14 |issue=1 |pages=56–8 |date=January 1959 |pmid=13609920 |doi= |url=}}
==External links== *[http://amphilsoc.org/mole/view?docId=ead/Mss.B.P312-ead.xml American Philosophical Society Raymond Pearl Papers] * {{Biographical Memoirs|pearl-raymond}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2010}}
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Pearl, Raymond}} [[Category:1879 births]] [[Category:1940 deaths]] [[Category:People from Farmington, New Hampshire]] [[Category:University of Michigan alumni]] [[Category:Biogerontologists]] [[Category:American biologists]] [[Category:Researchers in alcohol abuse]] [[Category:Presidents of the American Statistical Association]] [[Category:Fellows of the American Statistical Association]] [[Category:American statisticians]] [[Category:Writers from New Hampshire]] [[Category:Mathematicians from New Hampshire]]

'''Roman Igorevich Tsepov''' ([[Russian language|Russian]]: Роман Игоревич Цепов, (July 22, 1962, [[Kolpino, Saint Petersburg|Kolpino]], [[Leningrad Oblast]], [[USSR]] – September 24, 2004, [[Saint-Petersburg]]) was a [[Saint Petersburg]] [[businessman]] and [[confidant]] to [[Vladimir Putin]] during Putin's work at the [[Saint Petersburg City Administration]]. Born Belinson, Tsepov changed his [[surname]] upon marriage to Tsepova. Tsepov was suspected of criminal and corruption activity.
== Biography == Upon graduation from the Supreme Political school of the [[Russian Ministry of Internal Affairs|Ministry of Internal Affairs of the USSR]], Tsepov served in the [[Internal Troops]] as a [[political commissar]]. In 1990, he retired from the Ministry of Internal Affairs at the rank of [[Captain (land and air)|captain]].
== "Baltik-Eskort" == In 1992, Tsepov founded the security firm "Baltik-Eskort". The idea to create this agency belonged to the future Putin's bodyguard [[Viktor Zolotov]] who later oversaw this agency as a member of the [[Active reserve (KGB)|active reserve]].<ref name="Assassins">[[Yuri Felshtinsky]] and [[Vladimir Pribylovsky]] ''The Age of Assassins. The Rise and Rise of Vladimir Putin'', Gibson Square Books, London, 2008, {{ISBN|1-906142-07-6}}, pages 260-262.</ref> The firm provided protection to high ranking Saint Petersburg officials, including the city mayor [[Anatoly Sobchak]] and his family, as well as the vice-mayor [[Vladimir Putin]]. In this role, Tsepov also acted as an "intermediary between Putin and business". At the same time, "Baltik-Eskort" rendered security services to a number of criminal leaders, in particular Aleksandr Malyshev, the leader of "Malyshev's gang" and his family and several figures of the [[Tambov Gang]].<ref name=gurin>[http://www.jamestown.org/edm/article.php?article_id=2368580 Roman Tsepov, R.I.P] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930155103/http://www.jamestown.org/edm/article.php?article_id=2368580 |date=2007-09-30 }} by Charles Gurin, [[Eurasia Daily Monitor]] #93, September 27, 2004</ref>
== Criminal activity == In 1994, Tsepov was arrested on charges of illegal storage of weapons and drugs. It is rumored that the real reason for arrest was gathering of "protection" money to secure [[gambling]] licenses from city office of Vladimir Putin.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mn.ru/issue.php?2004-37-14 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2006-12-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060828033102/http://www.mn.ru/issue.php?2004-37-14 |archivedate=2006-08-28 |df= }}</ref><ref name=stringer>http://www.stringer.ru/publication.mhtml?Part=0&PubID=1269</ref> .<ref name=whoiswho>{{cite web |url=http://www.whoiswho.ru/russian/Password/papers/15r/putin/st5.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2006-12-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927222240/http://www.whoiswho.ru/russian/Password/papers/15r/putin/st5.htm |archivedate=2007-09-27 |df= }}</ref><ref name=gazeta>Роман Цепов. "Жертва необратимого процесса" "На нем очень многое держалось в Питере" [[Gazeta.ru]] 26 September 2004 [http://www.compromat.ru/main/putin/tsepov1.htm Online copy]</ref> Starting in 1993, there were five unsuccessful attempts on Roman Tsepov's life. His name appears in several criminal investigations, the last one being in March 1998 on charges of [[extortion]] of 70 thousand dollars [http://www.mk-piter.ru/2004/09/29/026/][http://www.apn-spb.ru/publications/print359.htm]. Tsepov went into hiding and fled to [[Czech Republic]]<ref name=stringer/> .<ref name=whoiswho/><ref name=gazeta/>
== Prominent businessmen == Upon Vladimir Putin's coming to power, Tsepov became one of the most influential figures in the financial and political life of Saint Petersburg. He took part in the [[First inauguration of Vladimir Putin|first presidential inaugural ceremony]] of Vladimir Putin. Tsepov's power and influence were attributed to his close association with then Minister of Internal Affairs [[Rashid Nurgaliyev]], the chief of [[Presidential Security Service]] [[Viktor Zolotov]] (Zolotov attended Tsepov's funeral<ref name=Polonium>[http://www.newspb.org/modules.php?name=News&file=print&sid=561 Николай АНДРУЩЕНКО. Полоний и три Владимира. Газета "НОВЫЙ ПЕТЕРБУРГЪ", №49(813), 21.12.2006 г]</ref><ref>[http://www.apn-spb.ru/publications/print359.htm Пакт Матвиенко-Медведева]</ref><ref name=Svoboda>[http://www.svobodanews.ru/articlete.aspx?exactdate=20070112175720537 Виктор Резунков, Игорь Корольков. Расследование отравления радиоактивным изотопом Романа Цепова, бывшего телохранителя Анатолия Собчака и Владимира Путина. Радио "Свобода", 12.01.07] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930170902/http://www.svobodanews.ru/articlete.aspx?exactdate=20070112175720537 |date=2007-09-30 }}</ref>) and deputy head of [[Russian presidential administration|presidential administration]] [[Igor Sechin]].He was also affiliated with Saint Petersburg branches of the [[Russian Ministry of Internal Affairs]] and [[Federal Security Service of the Russian Federation|FSB]] <ref name=compromat>[http://compromat.ru/main/putin/tsepov1.htm Роман Цепов. "Жертва необратимого процесса"]</ref> <ref> [http://kurg.rtcomm.ru/week.shtml?m=3&y=2004&cat=17&wid=225 Центр Кургиняна. Путин и политика]</ref> <ref>[http://www.skandaly.ru/news/news484.html СПРАВКА В ОТНОШЕНИИ ПУТИНА В В ]</ref> <ref>[http://www.mn.ru/print.php?2004-37-15 Цепов был мне не чужим"]</ref> <ref>[http://www.novayagazeta.ru/data/2004/71/07.html Николай Донсков. ПОЧЕМУ ПОГИБ ОХРАННИК ПРЕЗИДЕНТА]</ref> .<ref>[http://www.bankpress.ru/archive/2135359.html Bankpress.ru: На смену Борису Йордану приходит Роман Цепов<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Journalists named Roman Tsepov "a security oligarch"]<ref>[http://www.lawlinks.ru/print.php?id=11064 Павел Луспекаев. Генералам нужен злодей?]</ref> .<ref>[http://old.flb.ru/material.phtml?id=31505 Агентство федеральных расследований. Роман Цепов умер от неизвестной болезни]</ref><ref>[http://www.lenpravda.ru/readingreg1.phtml?id=2997 Фарма-мать зовет?]</ref> Regarding all this real or rumored activity, Tsepov stated: "For some reason all the time Tsepov appeared to be the most convenient figure for rumors. Elections - Tsepov. Criminal investigations, tranches, credits, fuel business, security, a casino - Tsepov. Personnel rearrangements - me too. The [[éminence grise|grey cardinal]] necessarily should exist at a king's court".<ref>[http://www.lenpravda.ru/reading1.phtml?id=2986 Атака серых кардиналов. "Ленинградская правда", 17.06.2002]</ref> In the summer of 2004, Tsepov was rumored to attempt to mediate between the government and [[YUKOS]].<ref name=rferl>[http://www.rferl.org/featuresarticle/2006/12/888236cc-139d-4212-a28d-88451fdaccab.html Russia: The KGB's Post-Soviet 'Commercialization'] by Victor Yasmann, [[Radio Free Europe]] / [[Radio Liberty]], December 20, 2006.</ref>
== Death by poisoning == On 11 September 2004, Tsepov visited colleagues at a local [[FSB (Russia)|FSB]] office where he had a cup of tea. On the same day, he felt unwell after which a very serious disease developed with symptoms such as vomiting, diarrhoea and sudden drop of white blood cells.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/mar/06/alexander-litvinenko-and-the-most-radioactive-towel-in-history|title=Alexander Litvinenko and the most radioactive towel in history|last=Harding|first=Luke|date=2016-03-06|newspaper=The Guardian|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077|access-date=2016-03-12}}</ref> Treated in Hospital 31 in Saint Petersburg, he died on 24 September. A [[Autopsy|postmortem]] investigation found a poisoning by an unspecified [[radioactive material]]. He had symptoms similar to [[Aleksander Litvinenko]].<ref name=Polonium/><ref name=Svoboda/><ref name=timesonline>[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/article/0,,2087-2484298,00.html The Putin bodyguard riddle], [[The Sunday Times (UK)|The Sunday Times]], December 3, 2006</ref>
== Trivia == After playing a small part in [[Vladimir Bortko]]'s [[mini-series]] ''[[Banditskiy Peterburg: Advokat]]'' (2000) Tsepov co-produced the [[Vladimir Bortko]]'s [[mini-series]] ''[[My Honor]]'' (2004). The series was awarded a [[TEFI]], the highest television award in [[Russia]], as best film. <ref name=sptimes>[http://www.sptimes.ru/index.php?action_id=2&story_id=1697 'King of Shadows' Poisoned], The [[St. Petersburg Times (Russia)|St. Petersburg Times]] #1007 (74), September 28, 2004.</ref>
== See also == * [[Aleksandr Litvinenko]]
== References == {{reflist|2}}
==External links== *[http://www.isn.ethz.ch/news/sw/details.cfm?ID=17078 The KGB's post-Soviet "commercialization"] *{{nl icon}} [https://web.archive.org/web/20070929130535/http://weblogs.nrc.nl/weblog/moskou/2006/12/04/de-gifconnectie-yukos-st-petersburg/ De gifconnectie Yukos-St Petersburg]
==External links in Russian== * [http://www.spb-business.ru/show.php?directory=80099 Охранное предприятие «Балтик-Эскорт] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070523131654/http://www.aprb.spb.ru/10let/p24.htm ООО. «Балтик-Эскорт» (справка)] * [http://2005.novayagazeta.ru/nomer/2005/22n/n22n-s00.shtml Связной с прошлым] * [http://www.mn.ru/issue.php?2004-25-55 Час мародера] * [http://2004.novayagazeta.ru/nomer/2004/72n/n72n-s15.shtml Охранник петербургских тайн] * [http://www.lenpravda.ru/gate.phtml?id=1184 Роман Цепов «помогал хоть чёрту»] * [http://www.pravda.ru/news/accidents/25-09-2004/26324-0 Кто убил бывшего охранника Путина?] * [http://grani.ru/president/m.77298.html Отравлен бывший глава охраны Путина] * [http://www.compromat.ru/main/putin/tsepov1.htm Роман Цепов. «Жертва необратимого процесса»]. * [http://www.compromat.ru/main/putin/tsepov6.htm Б.Ливанов. Смерть Романа Цепова]

revision.text:
{{UDP|date=July 2018}} {{Infobox medical person | name = Simon Ourian | image = Simon Ourian.png | caption = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1966|12|11}} | birth_place = Iran | nationality = | education = {{unbulleted list| [[California State University]]|[[Wayne State University]]}} | years_active = | known_for = | profession = Physician | field = [[general practitioner ]] | work_institutions = Epione Beverly Hills | specialism = Cosmetic Dermatology | website = }} '''Simon Ourian''', M.D founded Epione Beverly Hills in 1998 in Beverly Hills, California.<ref>{{cite web |title=Drive And Dedication: The Road To Success Of Epione Beverly Hills Founder Dr. Simon Ourian |url=https://www.entrepreneur.com/article/314346 |publisher=[[Entrepreneur (magazine)|Entrepreneur]] |accessdate=28 June 2018 |date=June 2, 2013}}</ref> Ourian is credited for developing the Coolaser and Coolbeam procedures. His clients include celebrities like the Kardashian-Jenner family,<ref>{{cite web |author1=Emily Siegel |title=We Tried Dr. Simon Ourian's CoolLaser Treatment |url=http://coveteur.com/2018/02/19/dr-simon-ourian-coollaser-treatment-review/ |publisher=Coveteur |accessdate=28 June 2018 |date=February 19, 2018}}</ref> Victoria’s Secret supermodels, Hollywood actors and musicians.<ref name="mogul">{{cite web |author1=Bhavna Anna Guyadeen |title=An Interview with the Doctor to the Stars Dr. Simon Ourian |url=https://onmogul.com/stories/an-interview-with-the-doctor-to-the-stars-dr-simon-ourian |publisher=[[Mogul (website)]] |accessdate=28 June 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |author1=Nadine Baggott |title=The Truth About The Doctor Reshaping Hollywood |url=https://graziadaily.co.uk/beauty-hair/skin/dr-simon-ourian-kardashian-doctor/ |publisher=[[Grazia]] |accessdate=28 June 2018 |date=September 13, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |author1=Ben Hoyle |title=Are you ready for your butt lift? |url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/are-you-ready-for-your-bottom-lift-rqdncrp7f |publisher=[[The Times]] |accessdate=28 June 2018 |date=June 18, 2016}}</ref>
==Early life and education== Ourian was born in Iran and moved the [[Los Angeles]] in the 1980s with his parents.<ref>{{cite web |author1=Anil Bhoyrul |title=A cut above: Dr Simon Ourian, cosmetic surgeon to the stars |url=https://www.arabianbusiness.com/style/399676-abe-1925-cut-above-the-rest |publisher=[[Arabian Business]] |accessdate=2 July 2018 |date=June 29, 2018}}</ref> His inclination towards cosmetic dermatology started at a young age when he saw the effect of plastic surgery on movie actors.<ref>{{cite web |author1=Kathleen Hale |title=Is Teenage Plastic Surgery a Feminist Act? |url=https://www.harpersbazaar.com/culture/features/a9555312/teenage-plastic-surgery-feminism/ |publisher=[[Harper's Bazaar]] |accessdate=28 June 2018 |date=May 25, 2017}}</ref>
He received his undergraduate degree in the field of [[molecular biology]] from the [[California State University]], Northridge, and his medical degree from [[Wayne State University]] in Michigan. Ourian did his residency at UCLA.<ref name="mogul"/>
He is married to Sharon Naim Ourian.
==Professional experience== After completing his education, Ourian started his own practice. He worked on his techniques and tested non-invasive procedures on himself. Ourian worked with the Fibonacci sequence to study facial elements and patterns.<ref>{{cite web |title=Meet cosmetic surgeon to the Kardashians, Dr Simon Ourian |url=http://english.alarabiya.net/en/life-style/entertainment/2017/10/30/EXCLUSIVE-Meet-cosmetic-surgeon-to-the-Kardashians-Dr-Simon-Ourian-.html |publisher=[[Al Arabiya]] |accessdate=28 June 2018 |date=October 30, 2017}}</ref>
In 1998, he founded the Epione Beverly Hills. He developed Coolaser for clearing acne and discoloration for darken skin tone and Coolbeam to get rid of stretch marks. He also created my Vibrata, a tool for minimizing pain, which is used by doctors around the globe.<ref>{{cite web |author1=Bhavna Anna Guyadeen |title=The Modern-Day Sculptor - An Interview with the Surgeon To The Stars |url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/590c6966e4b056aa2363d3e5 |publisher=[[HuffPost]] |accessdate=28 June 2018 |date=May 5, 2017}}</ref> Ourian uses various laser technology and non-invasive aesthetic procedures for the correction or reversal of a variety of conditions.
===Coolaser=== Ourian developed the Coolaser technology, and it has been used by celebrities such as [[Olivia Culpo]] and Kim Kardashian. It involves cooling the treatment area with a special device that emits a series of light pulses across the surface of the skin to stimulate cell repair and collagen growth.<ref>{{cite web |author1=Alex Warner |title=Olivia Culpo Just Showed Us The Trick Behind Her Insanely Glowy Skin |url=https://www.marieclaire.com/beauty/a19563557/olivia-culpo-coolaser-skin-treatment/ |publisher=[[Marie Claire]] |accessdate=28 June 2018 |date=March 22, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |author1=Cristina Gibson |title=Jenna Dewan Tatum Shares Low-Makeup Selfie, Reveals How She Got Rid of Melasma |url=https://www.usmagazine.com/stylish/news/jenna-dewan-tatum-reveals-how-she-got-rid-of-melasma/ |publisher=[[Us Weekly]] |accessdate=28 June 2018 |date=October 24, 2017}}</ref>
===Celebrity clients=== Ourian is the doctor for the entire Kardashian-Jenner clan. He gained popularity when Kim Kardashian acknowledged him as her cosmetic dermatologist. Ourian has performed several procedures on her sister [[Kylie Jenner]].<ref>{{cite web |author1=Bee Shapiro |title=Kylie Jenner’s Beauty Routine: How She Keeps It Real |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/10/fashion/kylie-jenner-beauty-regimen.html |publisher=[[The New York Times]] |accessdate=28 June 2018 |date=September 8, 2015}}</ref> He has also worked on [[Malika Haqq]], [[Brandi Maxiell]], Miss Colombia, Meghan James, [[Lady Gaga]], beauty YouTuber Nikkie,<ref>{{cite web |author1=JILLIAN RUFFO |title=Kim Kardashian Reveals the Laser Treatments That Perfected Her Post-Baby Body |url=https://people.com/style/kim-kardashian-shares-favorite-laser-treatments/ |publisher=People (magazine) |accessdate=28 June 2018 |date=February 6, 2018}}</ref> and Lisa Vanderpump<ref>{{cite web |author1=Cristina Gibson |title=Exclusive: Lisa Vanderpump Reveals Whether She’s Had a Facelift, Botox, Fillers |url=https://www.usmagazine.com/stylish/news/lisa-vanderpump-talks-botox-plastic-surgery-fillers/ |publisher=[[Us Weekly]] |accessdate=28 June 2018 |date=October 25, 2017}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Ourian, Simon}} [[Category:1966 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Iranian physicians]]

revision.comment: /* Comparison with other sleepiness assessments */[[User:JCW-CleanerBot#Logic|task]], replaced: Neurol → Neurology using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{About|the sleep questionnaire|the type of Asian shark catfish called Swai|Pangasius}}
The '''sleep–wake activity inventory''' ('''SWAI''') is a subjective multidimensional questionnaire intended to measure sleepiness.
==The instrument== The SWAI consists of 59 items that provide six subscale scores: excessive daytime sleepiness, nocturnal sleep, ability to relax, energy level, social desirability, and psychic distress.<ref name="Rosenthal et al.">{{cite journal |author1=Rosenthal L. |author2=Roehrs T.A. |author3=Roth T |last-author-amp=yes |year=1993 |title=The sleep-wake activity inventory: a self-report measure of daytime sleepiness |journal=Biol Psychiatry |pmid=8292685 |volume=34 |issue=11 |pages=810–820 |doi=10.1016/0006-3223(93)90070-T}}</ref> Each item is rated on a 1 to 9 semicontinuous Likert type scale from "always" to "never", based on the previous seven days.<ref name="Rosenthal et al."/> The SWAI was normed on 554 subjects in the early 1990s and is currently being validated or has been validated in multiple languages, including Spanish, French and Dutch.
For the ''excessive daytime sleepiness'' subscale (SWAI-EDS), a score of 40 or below indicates excessive sleepiness, a score of between 40 and 50 indicates possible sleepiness and a score of greater than 50 is normal.
A short form of the SWAI exists that contains items for the ''excessive daytime sleepiness'' and ''nocturnal sleep'' subscales only.
==Comparison with other sleepiness assessments== The SWAI has been compared to the [[multiple sleep latency test]] (MSLT), which is an objective measure that is considered the gold standard of sleepiness assessment; it measures [[sleep onset latency]] during several daytime opportunities. The SWAI-EDS has been found to correlate moderately to highly with average MSLT scores.<ref name="Rosenthal et al."/>
Other sleepiness scales, including the [[Stanford sleepiness scale]] and the [[Epworth sleepiness scale]] (ESS), exist. However, the ESS does not correlate as highly with the MSLT as the SWAI.<ref name="Chervin et al.">{{cite journal |author1=Chervin R.D. |author2=Aldrich M.S. |year=1999 |title=The Epworth sleepiness scale may not reflect objective measures of sleepiness or sleep apnea |journal=Neurology |volume=52 |issue=1 |pages=125–131 |doi=10.1159/000023448}}</ref> The ESS is currently the most prevalent measure of excessive sleepiness.
==History== The SWAI was developed by Drs. Leon Rosenthal, Timothy Roehrs and Tom Roth at the Sleep Disorders and Research Center at the Henry Ford Hospital in Detroit, Michigan.
==References== <references/>
{{DEFAULTSORT:Sleep-wake activity inventory}} [[Category:Sleep]] [[Category:Tools]] [[Category:Anthropometry]]

[[File:Spiral plater pattern on petri dish.jpg|thumb|A photograph of a Petri dish with a spiral pattern dispensed using an integrated spiral plater on a Tecan robot. The media used was a purple color to illustrate the resulting pattern, normally a transparent media would be used.]]
A '''spiral plater''' is an instrument used to dispense a liquid sample onto a [[Petri dish]] in a [[spiral]] pattern. Commonly used as part of a [[Colony-forming unit|CFU]] count procedure for the purpose of determining the number of microbes in the sample.<ref name="initial article">J. E. Gilchrist, J. E. Campbell, C. B. Donnelly, J. T. Peeler, and J. M. Delaney [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/4632851 "Spiral Plate Method for Bacterial Determination"], ''[[Appl Microbiol. ]]'', 1973 February; 25(2): 244–252., {{PMC|380780}}</ref> In this setting, after spiral plating, the Petri dish is incubated for several hours after which the number of colony forming microbes (CFU) is determined. Spiral platers are also used for research, clinical diagnostics and as a method for covering a Petri dish with [[bacteria]] before placing antibiotic discs for [[Antibiotic sensitivity|AST]].
== Mode of action == The spiral plater rotates the dish while simultaneously dispensing the liquid and either [[linear motion|linearly moving]] the dish or the dispensing tip. This creates the common spiral pattern. If all movements are done in constant speed, the spiral created would have a lower concentration on the outside of the plate than on the inside. More advanced spiral platers provide different options for spiral patterns such as constant concentration (by slowing down the spinning and / or the lateral movements) or exponential concentration (by speeding up the spinning and / or the lateral movements).
== In food and cosmetic testing == Spiral plating is used extensively for microbiological testing of food, milk and milk products and cosmetics. It is an approved method by the FDA.<ref name="fda bam">{{cite web|url=http://www.fda.gov/Food/FoodScienceResearch/LaboratoryMethods/ucm063346.htm |title=BAM: Aerobic Plate Count |publisher=Fda.gov |date=2009-01-27 |accessdate=2013-10-01}}</ref> The advantage of spiral plating is less plates used versus plating manually because different concentrations are present on each plate.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.foodsafetymagazine.com/magazine-archive1/junejuly-2011/advances-in-spiral-plating-increase-reproducibility-and-cost-savings/ |title=Advances in Spiral Plating Increase Reproducibility and Cost Savings |publisher=Food Safety Magazine |date= |accessdate=2013-10-01}}</ref><ref name="initial article"/> This also makes it harder to count the colonies and requires special techniques and equipment.<ref name="fda bam"/>
== Stand-alone vs. Add-on == Spiral platers are either available as stand-alone instruments that are fed manually with plates and samples or fed automatically using dedicated stackers. Alternatively spiral platers are available as integrated devices as part of larger automated platforms. In this case a larger workflow is often automated, e.g. plating, [[Incubator (culture)|incubation]] and [[Colony counter|counting]].
== References == {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Biological techniques and tools]] [[Category:Food safety]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox university | name = Sylhet MAG Osmani Medical College | native_name = সিলেট এম.এ.জি ওসমানী মেডিকেল কলেজ | native_name_lang = bn | image = MAG Osmani Medical College logo.png | image_size = | image_alt = | caption = Logo of Sylhet MAG Osmani Medical College | other_name = <!-- or: | other_names = --> | former_name = Sylhet Medical College | established = {{start date|1962}} | type = [[Public university|Public]] [[medical school]] | academic_affiliation = [[Shahjalal University of Science and Technology|SUST]] | principal = Morshed Ahmed Chowdhury | director = Brig. Gen. A K Mahbubul Hoque | academic_staff = 160 | administrative_staff = 350 | students = 1,400 | undergrad = 1,000 | postgrad = 400 | doctoral = | other = | city = [[Sylhet]] | state = | country = [[Bangladesh]] | coor = {{Coord|24.9005|N|91.8532|E|region:BD_type:edu|display=inline,title}} | campus = [[Urban area|Urban]] | language = English | website = {{URL|magosmanimedical.com/}} | footnotes = }} [[File:Limerick SOMC.jpg|thumb|Students of Sylhet M.A.G Osmani Medical College performing in the college's intern ending program of 48th batch.]] '''Sylhet MAG Osmani Medical College''' ('''SOMC''') ({{lang-bn|সিলেট এম.এ.জি ওসমানী মেডিকেল কলেজ}}) is a [[Public university|government]] [[medical school]] in [[Bangladesh]], established in 1962. It is located in [[Sylhet]]. Originally named "Sylhet Medical College", it was renamed in 1986 in honour of General [[Muhammad Ataul Gani Osmani]], Commander-in-chief of [[Bangladesh Army]] during the [[Bangladesh Liberation War]] of 1971. The college is affiliated with [[Shahjalal University of Science and Technology]] under the School of Medical Sciences.
It offers a five-year course of study leading to a [[Bachelor of Medicine, Bachelor of Surgery]] (MBBS) degree. A one-year [[internship]] after [[graduation]] is compulsory for all graduates. The degree is recognised by the [[Bangladesh Medical and Dental Council]]. It admits approximately 200 undergraduate and a good number of postgraduate students every year.
It also offers 4 year's course on [[Dental Degree|Bachelor Of Dental Surgery]]. (BDS)<ref>magosmanimedical.com</ref>
==Campus== [[File:Sylhet MAG Osmani Medical College Building.jpg|thumb|left]] [[File:Language Movement Monument SOMC.jpg|thumb|right]]
The college and hospital extends over an area of 206,355 sq m divided into new site and old site. The Sylhet MAG Osmani Medical college situated in the new site covers an area of 191,977 sq M.
* Old campus * New campus * Model family planning clinic * Nuclear medicine center * Sylhet Nursing College
Main campus comprises individual facilities of: * A three-storied College building complex, * A five-storied 1000 bed large Hospital building complex, * A Nuclear Medicine unit, and Model Family Planning clinic * The Nurses training institute also run along with the medical courses.
Other many nearby hospitals are also affiliated with main academic schedule. These include: * Shahid Dr. Shamsuddin Ahmed General Hospital, * Leprosy Hospital, * TB clinic, Infectious disease Hospital and * The nearby Thana Health Complexes.
=== Hostel === There are five hostels for boys' & four for the girls'.
Boys' hostels includes - 1. Shahid Dr.Shamsuddin Ahmed Hostel 2. Abu Sina Hostel 3. Colonel Zia Hostel 4. Hazrat Shahjalal Hostel 5. Shahid Dr. Milon Intern Hostel.
Girls' hostels includes - 1. Dr. Dilruba Begum Hostel 2. Dr. Shayamol Kanti Lala Hostel 3. Hazrat Shahporan Hostel 4. Intern Hostel ( female)
==Academics==
[[File: Exam hall SOMC.jpg|300 px|thumb|Exam hall]] Sylhet MAG Osmani Medical College now offer 20 postgraduate courses. The presently available courses are M.D. (Internal medicine, Pediatrics and Cardiology), M.S. (|General Surgery, Obstetrics & Gynaecology, Ophthalmology, Pediatric surgery and Orthopaedics), M.Phil (Anatomy, Biochemistry, Pharmacology, Microbiology, Pathology and Psychiatry), one year Diploma (Forensic Medicine, Clinical Pathology, Child Health, Anesthesia, Dermatology & Venereal Disease and Obstetrics Gynaecology). The college now has more than 150 faculty members, around 350 staffs for 1000 undergraduate students and around 400 postgraduate students. All the courses are certified by Shahjalal University of Science and Technology (both undergraduate and postgraduate courses) are recognized by the National regulatory agency [[Bangladesh Medical and Dental Council]].<ref>http://bmdc.org.bd/recognized-medical-and-dental-colleges/</ref>
* Undergraduate Courses : M.B.B.S., BDS * Post Graduate Courses: ** Diploma - DA, DCP, DCH, DDV, DFM, DGO ** M.Phil - Anatomy, Biochemistry, Pharmacology, Microbiology, Pathology and Psychiatry ** M.D. - Internal Medicine, Pediatrics, Cardiology. ** M.S. - General Surgery, Ophthalmology, Orthopedic Surgery, Urology, Pediatric Surgery, Obstetrics & Gynecology
Two journals are published. Both are BMDC recognized. These are # Osmani Medical Teacher's Association Journal (OMTAJ), published in January and July every year. # Bangladesh Medical Journal, published twice yearly by BMA.
==See also== * [[List of medical colleges in Bangladesh]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
